DIV1.P: THE TRAGEDY OF HOFFMAN OR A Reuenge for a Father.
As it hath bin diuers times acted with great applause, at the Phenix in Druery-lane.
LONDON, Printed by I. N. for Hugh Perry, and are to bee sold at his shop, at the signe of the Harrow in Brittaines-burse. 1631.

DIV1.HEAD: TO HIS MVCH Honored Friend, Master Richard Kiluert.
DIV1.P: I Know you, and in that your worth, which I honour more, then greatnesse in a Patron: this Tragedy hapning into my hands, I haue now aduentured it vnto the Presse, and wanting both a Parent to owne it, and a Patron to protect it, am fayne to Act the Fathers part, and haue aduentu∣red to addresse it vnto your Worthy selfe; vnder whose wings it flyes for a new birth: it hath passed the Stage already with good applause, and I doubt not, but from you it shall receiue a kinde welcome, who haue alwaies bin a true Fauourer of Artes and Learning; and from your selfe I haue receiued so many noble curtesies, that I shall alwayes rest

SP.SPEAKER: Hoffman.
SP.L: HEnce Clouds of melancholy
le be no longer subiect to your sismes,
But thou deare soule, whose nerues and artires
n dead resoundings summon vp reuenge,
And thou shalt hate, be but appeas'd sweete harse
The dead remembrance of my liuing father
SP.STAGE: strikes ope a cur∣taine where ap∣peares a body.
SP.L: And with a hart as aire, swift as thought
I'le excuse iustly in such a cause
Where ruth leadeth, what coward would not fight
Ill acts moue some, but myne's a cause is right
See the powers of heauen in apparitions
And fight full aspects as inened
That thus tardy am to doe an act
which iustice and a fathers death exites,
Like threatening methors antedates destruction.
Againe I come, I come, I come,
Bee silent thou igies of faire virtue
That like a goodly syen wear't pluckt vp
By murderous, winds, infectious blasts and gusts
I will not leaue thee, vntill like thy selfe,
I'ue made thy enemies, then hand in hand
Wee'le walke to paradise—againe more blest
Ile to yon promonts top, and their suruey,
What shipwrackt passengers the belgique sea
Casts from her fomy entrailes by mischance.
Roare sea and winds, and with celestiall fires,
Quicken high projects, with your highest desires.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Yet this is somewhat like, but brambles, you are to bu∣sie, were I at Luningberge, and you catcht me thus, I should goe neere to aske you at whose suit, but now I am out of sent, And feare no eriants, for I thinke these woods and waters are common wealthes that need no such subiects nay they keepe not a Constable at sea, but a mans ouerwhelmd without order.—Well, dry land I loue thee, though thou swarme with millions of deuourers, yet hast thou no such swallow as the sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Thou lyest, there liues vpon the earth more easts
With wide deuouring throates, then can bee found
Of rauenous fishes in the Ocean:
The huge Leuiathan is but a shrimpe
Compar'd with our Balena on the land

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I am of your mind; but the Whale has a wide mouth
To swallow fleeting waters, and poore fish,
But we haue Epicures and Cormorants,
Whom neyther sea, nor land can hardly serue
They feed them fat, while armes and honour starue,
Desart lookes pale as death, like those bare bones.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Ha—amazd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Seest thou them trembling, slaue heere were Armes?
That seru'd the troath lesse state of Luningberge.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: So doe I sir serue the dukes sonne of the state,

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Ha, ha, I laugh to see how dastard feare
Hastens the death doomd wretch to his distresse,
Say didst thou serue the duke of Luningberge.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: His sonne Otho sir, 'me a poore follower of his
And my master is ayring of himselfe at your Cell,

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Is he that scapt the wracke young Luningberg?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I sir, the same sir, you are in the right sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Reuenge I kisse thee, vengeance y'are at liberty,
Wouldst thou hauing lost a father as I haue,
Whose very name dissolues my eyes to teares
Could duty and thy loue so different proue,
Not to auenge his death whose better part
Was thine, thou his, when he fell part of thee
Fell with him each drop, being part thine owne
And wouldst not be reveng'd;

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Yes on the murtherer,

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: On him, or anie man that is aied
Has but one unce of blood, of which hees part
He was my father, my hart still bleeds
Nor can my wounds be stopt, till an incision,
I'ue made to bury my dead father in:
Therefore without protraction, sighing, or excuses
Sweare to be true, to ayd assist me, not to stirre
Or contradict me in any enterprise
I shall now vndertake, or heareafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor
SP.L: I sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Were I perswaded that thou couldst shed teares,
As doth the Egyptian serpents neere the Nile;
If thou wouldst kisse and kill, imbrace and stabbe,
Then thou shouldst liue, for my inuictiue braine
Hath cast a glorious proiect of reuenge
Euen as thou kneel'st, wilt thou turne villaine speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Oh sir when was I otherwise, from my creation nothing else, I was made of no other stuffe, villany is my onely patri∣mony: though I bee an irreligious slaue, yet I beare a religious name, though I want courage, yet in talke, I'le put them all downe, though I haue nothing in me that is good:
SP.L: Yet i'le—

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Forbeare thy Lord is comming ile go in
And royally prouide for such a Prince,
Say thou hast met the kindest host aliue,
One that adores him, with no lesse zeale
Then rich men gold, or true religious heauen
Dissemble cunningly, and thou shalt prooue
the minion of my thoughts, friend to my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Well sir ne're feare me this is an excellent fellow
A true vilaine fitter for me then better company,
This is Hannce Hoffmans sonne.
SP.P: that stole downe his fathers Anotamy from the gallowes at Leningberge, I'tis the same vpon the dead scull ther's the iron Crowne that burnt his braines out, what will come of this, I neyther know nor care: but here comes my lord. Enter Otho. How chers my most noble, my most honorable, my most gracious; yea my most grieued prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: A fearefull storme

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: And full of horror.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Trust me Lorrique besides the inlie griefe
That swallowes my content when I perceiue
How greedily the feirce vnpitying sea, and waues,
Deuour'd our friends another trouble greeues my vexed eyes
With gashtly apperitions, strange aspects
Which eyther I doe certainely behold
Or else my soule deuining some sad fate
Fills my maginary powers with shapes
Hidious and horrid.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: My lord let your hart haue no commerce with that
Mart of idle imaginations, rouse vp your noblenesse
To apprehend comfort, kindnesse ease and what otherwise
Entertain'd so sollitary a place as this, can the
Antient subiect of the state of Leningberg collect
Tis I take it the sonne to that Viz-admirall that
Turn'd a terrible pirate.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Let vs turne backe into the sea againe
Yealding our bodies to the ruthles sound
That hath diuided vs and our late friends
Rather then see choyce Hoffman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor,
SP.L: Corrage braue Otho, hee'l vse thee kindly.
Heere he comes, sweete host heere is the dukes heire of
Leningberge doe homage and after entertaine him and me his
Follower with the most conspictious pleasures
That lies in thy poore hability.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Before I speake to my most sacred Lord
I ioyne my soft lipps to the ollid earth
And with an honord bennison I blesse
The hower, the place, the time of your arriue
For now my sauadge life, lead amongst beasts
Shalbe turn'd ciuell by your grarious helpe

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: I see thy true hearts loue drope downe in teares
And this imbrace shewes I am free from feares
My disturb'd blood runnes smoothly through my veines
And I am bold to call thee friend, bold to intreate
Food for by wrack I haue lost ship, friends and meat.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: You that attend my Lord enter the caue
Bring forth the homely Cakes theis hands prepar'd
While I intreat his excellence sit downe
Villaine bring nothing buta burning Crowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: What's that thou bidst him bring, a burning Crowne

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Still you suspect my harmelesse inocence
What though your father with the power state
And your iust vncle duke of Brusia
After my father had in thirty fights
Fill'd all their treasures with somens spoyles
And payd poore souldiors from his treasury
What though for this his merrits he was nam'd
A prescript out law for a little debt
Compeld to flie into the Belgique sound
And liue a pirate.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Prithee speake no more
Thou raysest new doubts in my troubled heart
By repetition of thy fathers wrongs

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Then hee was wrong'd you graunt but not by you,
You vertuous gentleman
Sate like a iust udge of the vnder-shades,
And with an vnchang'd Rhadamantine looke,
Beheld the fiesh mangled with many scars
Par'd from the bones of my offended father
And when hee was a bare anatomy,
You saw him chain'd vnto the common gallowes,

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Hoffman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Nay heare me patiently kind Lord
My innocent youth as guilty of his sinne,
Was in a dungeon hidden from the sunne,
And there I was condemn'd to endlesse night
Except I past my vow neuer to steale
My fathers fleshles bones from that base tree
I know nor who it was, I guesse your mother,
She kneeld and wept for me, (but you did not)
Beseeching from that vow I might be freed
Then did I sweare if Nations forraigne power
Compel'd me to take downe those naked bones
I neuer would release them from those chaines
Neuer intombe them, but immediately
Remoue them from that gallowes to a tree
I kept mine oath: looke Luningberg; tis done
Behold a father hang'd vp by his sonne

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Oh horrible aspect murtherer stand off
I know thou meanst mee wronge

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: My Lord behold these pretious twines of light
Burnt out by day eclipst when as the sunne
For shame obscur'd himselfe this deed was done
Where none but schrich owles sung, thou receptacle
thou organ of the soule;
Rest, goe rest, and you most louely Couplets
Leggs and armes reside, for euer heere
This is my last farewell, what doe you weepe?

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Oh Lorrique I am betrayd, slaue touch me not

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Not touch thee? yes, and thus trip downe thy pride.
You pla'ct my father in a Chaire of state:
This earth shall bee your throne, villaine come forth
And as thou mean'st to saue thy forfeit life,
Fixe on thy Masters head my burning Crowne,
While in these Cords, I in eternall bands
Binde fast his base and coward trembling hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Lorrique, art thou turn'd villaine to my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ile turne any thing sir rather then nothing, I was taken life promist to betray you, and I loue life so well, that I would not loose it for a Kingdome, for a Kings Crowne, an Empire.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: On with the Crowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Oh tortor aboue measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: My father felt this paine▪ when thou hadst pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Thy father dyed for piracy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Oh peace, had he biiudge himselfe, he would haue shew'd
He had bin clearer then the Christall morne!
But wretches sentenc'd neuer finde defence,
How euer guiltlesse bee their innocence,
No more did hee, no more shalt thou, no ruth
Pittied his winter age, none helps thy youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho
SP.L: Oh Lorrique tortor, I feele an Aetna burne
Within my braines, and all my body else
Is like a hill of Ice, all these Belgique seas
That now, surround vs cannot quench this flame
Death like a tyrant seazeth me vnawares,
My sinwes shrinke like leaues parcht with the sunne
My blood dissolues, nerues and tendons fayle
Each part's disioynted, and my breath expires
Mountsoule to heauen, my body burnes in fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Hee's gon.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Goe let him come Lorrique
This but the prologue to the'nsuing play.
The first step to reuenge, this seane is donne
Father I offer thee thy inurtherers onne.

DIV2.STAGE: Florish. Enter erdinand, Rodork, Lodowick, Mathias, Lucibet, erom, Stilt, attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Princes of Saxony and Austria,
Though your owne worsare of sufficient weight
To iustifie the honorable loue borne by Lodowick to bright Lucybell,
Yet since your parents liue and as I heare
There is betweene them some dissention,
Blame vs not for detaining yo thus long
Till we had notice how the businesse stood

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.L: Your royall entertaine great Ferdinand,
Exceeding expectation in our stay,
Bind vs to thanks, and if my brother please
To hold his challenge for a Turnament
In praise of Lucibellas excellence,
No doubt our father and the Austrian duke
Will be in person at so royall sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: We trust they will.

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: I doe assure your grace
The Austrian and the duke of Saxony
By true report of pilgrimes at my cell
From eyther of there courts set hetherward
Some sixe dayes since.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Thankes Rodorick for this newes
They are more welcome then the sad discourse
Of Leningberg our nephewes timeles wrake
Which addeth sorrow to the mourning giefes
Abound in vs for our Dutches death.

SP.SPEAKER: Ie.
SP.P:
I truly Princes, my father has had but hard lucke since your comming to his court, for ought I know you are bred of ill weather, come before you are sent for, yet if my most gratious father say you are welcome, I his more gratious sonne take you by the hands, though I can tell you my mothers death comes somewhat neere my heart, but I am a prince, and princes haue
power more then common people to subdue their passions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: We know your worthinesse is experienc't in all true wisedome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: True, I am no foole, I haue bin at Wittenberg, where wit growes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Peace thou vnshapen honor, my states shame,
My ages cosiue, and my blacke sinnes curse,
Oh hadst thou neuer bin, I had bin then,
A happy childlesse man, now among men,
I am the most vnhappie, one that knowes
No end of mine, and of my peoples woes.
I tell you Princesse, and most gracious maide;
I doe not weare these sable ornaments
For Isabel death, though she were deare,
Nor are my eyelids ouerflowne with teares,
For Otho of Luningberg, wrackt in the Soun,
Though he wer a my hope: but heer's my care,
A witesse foole must needs be Prussias hire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Well, and you were not my father,—s'nailes, and I would not draw rather then put vp the foole, would I might neuer winne this lady at tilt and turnament: s Knights, I defie you both, for her; euen you Lodowick, that loues her, and your brother that loues you: looke to me, Stilt, and I haue practis'd these two dayes: s'nailes god forgiue me to sweare, she shall not be carried away so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: We are glad to heare your grace so esolute.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: As I am a Prince, and a Dkes heire, though I say it my selfe, I am as full of resolution as the prowdest of you all

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: I thanke Prince Lodowick he ha's bound my youth
To bee the conquerers prize, and if my starres
Allott me to be yours, I will be prowd,
For how so ere you seeme not fashioned
Like mee, and cunning Courtiers; I protest,
By some small loue I beare thee in mine eie,
Your worthy beautie, wealth and dignity.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Heart you would not vnhorse Hercules for her fa∣ther, ile practice againe at Dantzike, you say in the Dukes meade; ile meete thee Mathias: ther's my gloue For a gauntle, though my father count me a foole, you shall finde me none.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Would I might neuer find thee any thing,
For thou indeede art nothing in steeme,
My sad soule sinkes with sorrow at thy sight,

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Health to the right gratious, generous, vertuous, and valorous Ferdinand Duke of Prussia.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Hermet dost thou not know this young mans face?
I'st not Lorique, that met vs at thy cell
With letters from our brother Luningberg?

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: It is that gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: I am no lsse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: thou saydst thou wast my nephewes play fellow,
Appointed to await his vertuous person,
How is it then thou wert so ill aduised
To take the land away, and forsake thy Lord?
Whom I haue neuer seene, nor neuer may,
Though in his life my hope and comfort lay.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Be it knowne right gracious: Lorrique had neuer so little grace, as to leaue his loued lord for weather or water, for torture or fire, for death or for life, since I first came to moue in a pilgrims proportion; much disguised, being so proper a man: but onely for those sixe words; that I was sent wholy to giue notice of his comming.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: But thou hast left him now sunke in the sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P:
I left the ship sunke, and his highnesse sau'd, for when all hope had left Master and pilot, sailer and swabber, I caus'd my Lord to leape into the cocke, and for feare she should be sunke with too much company; I caper'd out▪ and cut the cable: rowse, quoth the ship against the rocks, roomer cry I in the cocke, my Lord wept for the compa∣ny: I laught to comfort him; last by the power of heauen,
goodnesse of starrs, kindnesse of winds, mercy of the waues, our cocke and wee were cast a shore vnder Reeshopscurre, we clamberd vp, but hauing scap't drowning, were in dan∣ger of killing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: What there betided you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor,
SP.P: Marry Lord a young villaine, sonne of a damn'd pirate, a mayd rauisher.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Be briefe, what was he?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Clois Hoffman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Oh my heart! did the false rebell hurt his soueraignes sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Noe my Lord, the prince so hought and hoft him, that he had no other helpe but to his heeles, and then I, my good Lord, being rofooted, utstript him in running, tript him by strength, and in fine, finely cut's throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Where is the villaines body?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Marry euen heaued ouer the scarr, and sent a swim∣ming toward Burtholme, his old habitation; if it bee not intercepted by some Scale, Sharke, Sturgeon, or such like.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Where is our nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: He intends to stay at the same hermitage, where I saluted your excellence, with newes of my lords excellen∣cies intent, to visite you▪ for that his apparrell is some∣what sea-sicke, and he wants shift.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: A charriot, and rich robes attend Lorrique.
And his rewad, be thirteene hundred dollers,
For he hath driuen dolour from our heart.
Princes, and Princesse, in your kindest loue,
Attend our person to the hermitage,
where we shall meete the heire of two great States,
Rich Luningberg, and warlike Prussias,
Otho liuing, wee'l disinherit our fond sonne:
And blesse all Dantzike, by our sonne elect,
Hermet you haue at home, a guest of ours,
Your little cell, is a great princes court;
Had you bin there to entertaine young Otho,
He would haue tooke your welcome thankfully,
Where now he mournes, for want of company.

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: I will goe on before my gracious Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd,
SP.L: Nay I am iealous of my approaching ioy,
And fearefull, any eye but mine, should gaine
The pleasure of my glad diuining soule;
Forward come all, in my delight take part,
He that's now glad, addes ioy to gladnes heart.
If there liue ere a surgeon that dare say
He could doe better: ile play Mercury,
And like fond Marsias flea the Quacksaluer
There were a sort of filthy Mountebankes,
Exprt in nothing but in idle words,
Made a daies work, with their incision kniues
On my opprest poore father: silly man,
Thrusting there dastard fingers in his flesh,
That durst not while he liued, behold his face;
I haue fitted my anatomy
In a fair chaine to; father this youth scorn'd
When he was set in an ascending throne,
To haue you stand by him; would he could see,
How the case alters, you shall hang by him,
And hang afore him to, for all his pride,
Come image of bare death, ioyne side, to side,
With my long iniur'd fathers naked bones;
He was the prologue to a Tragedy,
That if my destinies deny me not,
Shall passe those of Thyestes, Tereus,
Iocasta, or Duke Iasons iealous wife;
So shut our stage vp, there is one act done
Ended in Othos death; 'twas somewhat single;
Ile fill the other fuller, if Lorrique,
That I haue late sworne to be murders slaue,
Sweares hee will protest me to be Othos,
Whom Prussia his vncle vnknowne loues;
If I be taken for him well: Oh then!
Sweet vengeance make me happiest of all men:
Prussia, I come as comets against change:
As apparitions before mortall ends;
If thou accept me for thy nephewe, so;
Vncle, ile vncle thee of thy proud life.
Father farewell, ile to the hermitage,
Where if I be receaued for Luningberg,
I will haue thy drie bones, sanguin'd all or'e
With thy foes bloud, Rhamnusia helpe thy priest,
My wrong thou know'st, my willingnesse thou seest.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus secundus.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Come Stilt, bestirre your stumpes; you know I must be a tilter.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: I my lord, I know you should be one, but I hope you are not so madd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: what dost thou count it madnesse to runne a tilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: I my Lord, for you that cannot sit a hobby, you'le hardly manage your tilthorse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Why? they say Stilt, that stone Mares are gentler, see if thou canst get me one of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Not afore next grasse; I could helpe you now to a stone mule, a stone asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Well, ile trie one course with thee at the halfe pike, and then goe, come draw thy pike.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: That's not your fit word; you must say, aduance your pike, and you must be here sir, and here, you'l neuer learne for all my teaching.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P:
I haue answered you Stilt, that Princes haue no need to bee taught, and I haue e'en determin'd with my selfe, not to runne at tilt, least I hazard my horse and harnesse:
therefore ile to the court, and onely see my new cousin, that they sayd was drownd: and then retire to my (astle at Helsen, and there write a new poem, that I haue taken paines in, almost these ten yeares: It is in prayse of picke∣toothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: That will be excellent my Lord, the barbers will buy those poems abominably.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Nay sirra, ile get a patent from the Duke, my father, for the Cum Priuilegio for that poem, Ad imprimendum solum; besides thou shalt haue a priniledge, that no man shall sell tooth pickes without thy seale: my father saies I am a foole, but I thinke I bestow my time to looke out for setting a new nappe vpon his thredbare Common wealth: Who's that knockes? who dares disturbe our honorable meditation? harke Stilt, dost thou see no noyse?

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: No, but I heare a noyse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ierom.
SP.P: A hall then; my father and my new cousen: stand aside, that I may set my countenance, my beard brush and mirror, Stilt, that set my countenance right to the mirror of Knight-hood, for your mirror of magistrates is some∣what to sober▪ how lik'st me?

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Oh excellent! heers your casting bottle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Sprinkle, good Stilt, sprinkle, for my late practize hath brought mee into strange fauour: ha mother of mee, thou hadst almost blinded the eyes of excellence; but omnia bene, let them approach now, and I appeare not like a Prince, let my father casheere me, as some say hee will.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Casheere you? no, doe but manage your body, and haue heere, and heere your congies, and then quid sequi∣tur, Stilt knowes, and all the court shall see.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Ferdinand leading Clois Hoffman: Mathias, and L∣dowick leading Lucibella: Lorrique, with other lords atten∣ding: comming neere the chayre of state, Ferdinand Ascends, places Hoffman at his feete, sets a Co∣ronet on his head, A Herald proclaimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.P: Ferdinand by the diuine grace, prince of Heidel∣berg lord of Pomer, and Duke of Prussia, for sundry reasons hm mouing, the quiet state of his people especially: which as a witlsse and insufficient prince, disinherits Ie∣rom Heidelberg his knowne sonne, and adopteth Otho of Iuningberg his sisters sonne, as heire, immediately to suc∣ceed after his death in all his prouinces. God saue Duke Ferdinand, and Otho his heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Amen, Heauen witnesse, how my heart is pleas'd,
With the conceit of Prussias after-peace,
By this election.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: Why? but heare you father▪

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Away, disturbe vs not, let's in and feast,
For all our country in our choyce is blest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Why, but Stilt, what's now to be done Stilt?

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Nay that's more then I know: this matter will trouble vs more then all your poem of picktooths, s'nailes: you were better be vnknighted then vnprinc'd, I haue lost all my hope of preferment, if this hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Noe more Stilt, I haue it heere; 'tis in my head, and out it shall not come, till red reuenge in robes of fire, and mad∣ding mischiefe runne and raue: they say I am a foole Stilt, but follow me; ile seeke out my notes of Machiauel, they say hee's an odd politician.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: I faith hee's so odd, that he hath driuen euen hone∣sty from all mens hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: Well, sword come forth, and courage enter in,
Brest breake with griefe; yet hold to be reueng'd:
Follow me Stilt; widdowes vnborne shall weepe,
And beardlesse boyes with armour on their backes
Shall beare vs out, Stilt we will tread on stilts,
Through the purple pauement of the court,
Which shall bee, let me see, what shall it be?
No court, but euen caue of misery.
Ther's an excellent speech Stilt, follow me, pursue me, will accquire,
And either die, or compasse my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Oh braue master, not a Lord: O, Stilt will stalke, and make the earth a stage,
SP.L: But hee will haue thee lord in spight of rage.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Rodorigo, and Austria's Duke, some followers.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Sir since you are content, you heere shall finde,
A sparing supper, but a bounteous minde:
Bad lodging, but a heart as free, and generous,
As that which is fed with generous blood,

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Your hermitage is furnish't for a prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: Last night this roofe couer'd the sacred heads
Of fiue most noble, faire, and gratious Princes,
Duke Ferdinand himselfe, and Otho his nephew,
The sonnes of Saxon, and he Austrian Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Oh god! that girle, which fled my Court and loue,
Making loue colour for her heedles flight,

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: Pardon great prince: are you the Austrian duke?

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Hermet I am, Saxons proud wanton sonns
Were entertaind like Priam's Firebrand
At Sparta: all our State gladly 'appear'd
Like chierfull Lacedemons, to receaue
Those Daemons that with magicke of their tongues,
Bewitch't my Lucibells my Helen's eares.

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: Who traueleth so late? who knockes so hard?
Turne to the east end of the Chappell, pray;
We are ready to attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Which is the way to Dantzike?

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: There is no way to Dantzike you can finde
Without a guide thus late, come neere I pray,

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: looke to our horses, by your leaue master Hermet,
We are soone bidden, and will proue bold guests:
God saue you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: That should bee Saxons tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Indeed I am the Duke of Saxony.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Then art thou father to lasciuious sonnes,
That haue made Austrea childles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: O subtill duke, thy craft appeares in framing thy ex∣cuse,
Thou dost accuse my yong sons innocence:
I sent them to get knowledge, learne the tongues,
Nor to be metamorphis' with the view
Of flattering beauty, peraduenture painted.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: No; I defie thee ohn of Saxony;
My Lucibell for beauty needs no art,
Nor doe I thinke the vertues of her minde
Euer inclind to this ignble course
But by the charmes and forcings of thy sonnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Oh would thou durst maintaine thy words prowd Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: I hope great Princes, neither of you dare
Commit a deede so sacrilegious: This holy cell
Is dedicated to the sonne of peace;
The foot of war neuer prophan'd this floore,
Nor doth wrath here with his consming voyce
Affright these buildings; charity with prayer,
Humility with abstinence combin'd,
Are heere the guardians of a grieued minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Father we obey thy voyce;
Duke Iohn of Saxony, receiue my faith;
Til our eares heare the true course thy sones
Haue taken with my fond and mis-led child.
I proclaime truce, Why dost thou ullen stand?
If thou meane peace, giue me thy Princely hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Thus doe I plight thee troth, and promise peace,

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Nay, but thy eyes agree not with thy heart;
In vowes of combination, ther's a grace
That shewes the intention in the outward face,
Looke cherefully, or I expect no leagu.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: First giue me leaue to view a while the person,
Of this Hemer, Austria note him well,
Is he not like your brother Rodorick?

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Hee's like him, but I heard he lost his life
Long since in Persia, by the Sophies warres.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: I heard so much my Lords, but that report
Was purely fain'd, spread by my erring tongue,
As double as my heart, when I was yonge▪
I am that Rodorick that aspir'd your throne;
That vile false brother who with rebell breath,
Drawne sword, and trecherous heart threatned your death▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: My brother I nay, then i'faith old Iohn lay by
Thy sorrowing thoughts, turne to thy wonted veyne,
And be madd Iohn of Saxony againe.
Mad Rodorick, art aliue? my mothers so nne
Her ioy and her last birth; oh she coniurd me
To vse thee thus, and yet I banisht thee:
Body of me; I was vnkinde I know,
But thou deseru'st it then; but let it goe:
Say thou wilt leaue this life thus truly idle,
And liue a Statesman, thou shalt share in raigne,
Commanding all but me thy soueraigne.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: I thanke your Highnes; I will thinke on it:
But for my sinnes this sufferance is more fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Tut, title, tatle, tell not me of sinne.
Now Austria once againe thy Princely hand:
Ile looke thee in the face, and smile, and sweare,
If any of my sonnes haue wrong'd thy child,
Ile helpe thee in reuenging it my selfe;
But if as I beleeue they meane, but honor,
As it appeareth by these iusts proclaim'd.
Then thou shalt be content to name him thine,
And thy faire daughter ile account as mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Ah Austria! t'was a world when you and I
Ran these Carreers; but now we are stiffe and drie.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: I am glad you are so pleasant my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: T'was my old mood, but I was soone turn'd sad▪
With ouer grieuing for this long lost lad;
And now the Boy is growne, as old as I,
His very face as full of grauity.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Please your Graces enter,
I know the seruants that attend one me
By the appointment of Duke Ferdinand
By this haue couered.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Why then let's in: brother I trust, and brother
Hold you this hand, Rodorick hold thou the other,
By heauen my heart with happinesse is crow'nd,
In that my long lost brother now is found:

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: so run on fate, my destinies are good,
Reuenge hath made me great by shedding blood:
I am suppos'd the heire of Luningberg,
By which I am of Prussia Prince elect.
Good: who is wrong'd by this? Onely a foole:
And 'tis not fit that idiots should beare rule.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: My Lord I haue as you inioyn'd, intic't Saxons elder sonne to talke with you: and heere hee comes with his most excellent, amorous, and admirable Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.P: Ha'st thou the Hermets weeds for my disguise?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: All ready, fit, fit' in the next chamber, your beard is point-vice, not a haire amisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff
SP.L: Faithfull Lorrique in thy vnfaithfulnes:
I kisse thy cheeke, and giue thee in that kisse
The motie of all my earthly blisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Good: I am halfe a Monarke: halfe a fiend
Blood I begun in and in blood must end
SP.P: yet this Clois is an honest villaine, ha's conscience in his kil∣ling of men: he kils none but his fathers enemies, and there issue, 'tis admirable, 'tis excellent, 'tis well 'tis meritorious, where? in heauen? no, hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Now friend, where is prince Otho?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Sad, sir, and grieued.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Why? prithee why?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Alas I know not why.
The hermet Rodorigo talkt with him
Somewhat of you, and somewhat of the Duke,
About surprizing you and murdering Lodowick:
Or such a thing, nay sure 'twas such a thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Surprizing me and murdering Lodowicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: By whom? by what complot?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Sure by the Duke, the Duke's an odd old lad:
I know, this nigh ther's set a double guard,
And ther's some tricke in that: but patience:
Heere comes the Hermet: holy reuerent man!
SP.STAGE: Enter Clois Hoffman like a her.
SP.L: Somewhat important, wings his aged feete
With speedy nimblenesse: heauen graunt that all be well▪

SP.SPEAKER: Clois.
SP.L: Princes in pitty of your youth, your loue,
Your vertues, and what not, that may moue ruth,
I offer you the tender of your liues,
Which yet you may preserue: but if you stay,
Death and destruction waiteth your delay.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod,
SP.L: Who hath conspir'd our deathes? speake reuere man.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: The Duke of Prussia, doating on this face;
Worthy indeed of wonder, being so faire,
This night hath plotted, first to murder you;
The guard are set that you may not escape,
Within, without, and round about the court;
Onely one way, thorow Prince Otho his lodging
Is left; heere is the key, and for more proofe
Of my great zeale and care, on with these robes.
Within are Grecian habits for your heads;
Nay if you loue life do not stand amaz'd,
But take the path toward my hermitage,
Yet I aduize you, that you goe not in;
There may be plots to, for ought I know;
But turne downe by the riuer, ther's a way
Leads to a little Chappell; in that porch
Stay, till I visit you with better newes;

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I will but call my brother, and then goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: That were a going neuer to returne:
I'le send him after you, be well assur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Oh god! the Duke of Prussia grown thus false,
such shewes of freindship, and so little faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Come Lucibella lets embrace this meane,
Duke Ferdinand shall with a sorrowing heart,
Repent this base dishonourable plot:
Father, our fortunes if they sort aright,
shall with continuall thankfulnesse require
This vertuous and this charitable care:
Farwell: wee'l wait thee in the Chappell porch
Bring Prince Mathias our kind brother thither,
And thou shalt add good works to charity:
Once more farewell Lorrique; ther's for thee,
Commend me to thy Lord, tell him this wronge
Of his false vncle, shal meere full reuenge:
But doe to him our duties. Come chast, faire,
We must not now by and turnameut
Maintayne thy honor: for thy champion Knight,
Is for'st by treason to vnwilling flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: so runne to mischiefe: Oh my deare Lorrique
When I haue summ'd vp my account of death,
And rob'd those fathers of there lifes and ioy,
That rob'd mee of my ioy, my fathers life,
Thus thy hand claspt in mine, wee'l walke and meditate,
And boast in the reuenges I haue wrought;
That done; ile seat thee by m throne of state,
And make thee riuall in those gouernments,
That by thy secrecy thou li't me to;
Shalt be a Duke at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: I thanke your Grace, but pray resolue me,
what you now intend,
To these three Princes Lodowick, and Mathias,
And the thrice beautious Princesse Lucibell.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.P: Death certaine: call in Mathias, if my plot proue good, make one brother shed the others blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I am nimble as your thought, deuise, i'le execute what you command.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: A preious villaine: a good villaine too▪
Wll if he be no worse; that is doe worse,
And hony me in my death-stinging thoughts,
I will preferre him: he shall be prefer'd
To hanging peraduenture; why not? 'tis well
His sufferance heere may saue his soule from hell.
Hee comes; what newes my faithfull seruant? wher's the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Hee's talking with the lady Lucibell,
And when I said your Highnesse sent for him,
Hee 'gan with courtly salutations,
To take his leaue and to attend your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Well god-a-mercy friend, thou got'st me grace:
But more of that at leasure: take this gowne;
My cloake, a chaire; I must turne melancholy.
Second what ere I say, approoue my words,
That we may mooue Mathias to mad rage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: God saue your excellence: what sad, dull, heauy?
Or are you now in meditation
Which part to take to morrow at the Tilt?
The mead is ringd with tents of stranger Knights,
Whose rich deuices, and caparisons
Exceed the Persian Monark's, when he met
Destruction and pale death sent from the sword
Of Philips sonne, and his stout Macedons
Cheerely Prince Otho ther's such a warlike sight
That would stirre vp a leaden heart to fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: For honor and faire Luicbell.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Oh Prince Mathias! it is ill combin'd
When honor is with fickle beautie ioynd.
Where is your most Princely brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I cannot tell I left him with his loued Lucibell.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: But shee has got another loue,
Dishonored all this rich assembly,
Left the mmoriall of such infamy,
As cannot die while men haue memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: How? pay you how? what hath the princesse done?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: she with a Grecian is but new fled hence,
Belike some other loue of hers before:
Our tilt and turnament is spoild and crost.
The faire we should defend, her faith hath lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Fled with a Grecian? saw you them goe Prince Otho?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: I, I, I saw them goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And would not stay them?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: My true seruant knowes,
How at the sight of such inconstancy
My gentle heart was smitt with inward griefe
And I sunke downe with sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: s'death; what path? which way? that I may track her harlot-steps,
Fled now: gone now: ile goe seeke Lodowicke

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Nay then you add an irreligious worke,
To there lasciuious act; follow your selfe,
I and my man will beare your company
Lorrique, as I thinke, thou nam'dst a chappell,
A Hermet, some such thing: I haue lost the forme.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I heard her say, she could not trauell far,
He told her, they would rest the dead of night▪
Neere to a chappell, by a hermitage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Where is that chappell? wher's that hermitage?
If you loue honor Princely Luningberg,
Lets to that chappell: if you know the way,
That I may kill our shame, ere it se day.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Ile guide you to the chappell, ayd your arme▪
In your reuenge, against that Grecian,
But for the Lady spare her, she is faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I will doe what I can; oh hell of life!
Who, but a foole would striue to winne a wife?
shall we call Lodowick?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: no, t'would smite his soule in sunder, split his heart,
If he should heare of such adulterate wronge,
Couer the fault or punish as you please:
Yet I would saue her faine, for she deserue
pitty for beanty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Nothing, noe for nothing.
Shee is as harlots, faire, like guilded tombs
Goodly without; within all rottennes:
shee's like a painted fire vpon a hill,
set to allure the frost-nipt passengers,
And starue them after hope: she is indeed
As all such strumpets are, Angell in shew,
Diuell in heart: Come, come if you loue me goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Follow Lorrique; we are in the right way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: To hell I feare: tush let all feare goe by,
Whoo'l shun a bad way with good company.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus tertus.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Are you not faint diuinest Lucibell?

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Noe, the cleare moone strowes siluer in our path,
And with her moist eyes weepes a gentle dew
Vpon the the spotted pauement of the earth,
Whih softens euery flowre whereon I tread
Besides; all trauell in your company
Seemes but a walke made in some goodly bowre,
Where loues faire mother strips her paramoure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: This is the Chappell, and behold a banke,
Couer'd with sleeping flowers, that misse the Sunne:
Shall Wee repose vs till Mathias come?

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: The Hermet will soone bring him, let's sit downe▪
Nature, or art hath taught these boughes to spred,
In manner of an arbour o're the banke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: No, they bow downe as vailes to shadow you▪
And the fish flowers beguiled by the light
Of your celestiall eyes, open there leaues,
And when they entertaine the lord of day
You bring them comfort like the Sunne in May.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Come▪ come, you men will flatter beyond meane:
Will you sit downe? and talke of the late wronge
Intended by the Duke of Prussia?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Fairest forget it, leaue till we are cleare freed hence,
I will defie him, and cause all the knights
Assembled for our purpos'd turnament,
To turne there keene swords 'gainst his catiue head.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Prithee no more, I feele thy blood turne hot,
And wrath inflames thy spirit, let it cease;
Forgiue this fault, conuert this war to peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: O breath sweet touch with what a heauenly charme
Doe your soft fingers my wa-houghts disarme,
Prussia had reason to attempt my life
Inchanted by the magicke of these lookes,
That cast a luster on the blushing starrs.
Pardon chast Queene of beauty, make me proude
To rest my toild head on your tender knee,
My chin with sleepe is to my bosome bow'd;
Faire if you please a little rest with mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: No, ile be Centinell; ile watch for feare
Of venomous wormes, or wolues, or woluish theeues:
My hand shall fanne your eyes, like the film'd winge
Of drowsie morpheus; and my voyce shall sing
In a low compasse for a Lucibell.
Sleepe sweete, perhaps ile sleepe for company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I thanke you; I am drowsie, sing I pray;
Or sleepe: doe what you please, I am heauy, I;
God night to all our care: oh! I am blest
By this soft pillow where my head doth rest.
By my troth I am sleepy too: I cannot sing,
My heart is troubled with some heauy thing.
Rest one these violets, whilst I prepare,
In thy soft slumber to receiue a share:
Blush not chast Moone to see a virgin lie
So neere a Prince, 'tis noe immodestie:
For when the thoughts are pure, noe time, noe place,
Hath power to worke faire chastities disgrace;
Lodowick I claspe thee thus, so arme clip arme,
So sorrow fold them that wish true loue harme.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Art sure tha'st found them?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Looke, are these they?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Adulterer: stiumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Vnhumane deede to kill both.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Both haue abu'd our glory, both shall bleed,

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: how now! what haue ye done? my Lodowick bleeds
Some sauage beast hath fixt his ruthles fange
In my soft body: Lodowick, I faint▪
Deere wake; my Lodowick: alas what meanes
Your brest to be thus wet? I'st blood or sweat▪

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Who troubles me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Who is that? Mathias.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I, accursed I,

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Wher's the good Hermet? thanke him for his loue▪
Yet tell him; Ferdinand of Prussia
Hath a long arme; some murderer of his
hath kild vs sleeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Kild thee? oh no! I trust the carefull destinies deny
So hard a fate: 'tis I alone am kild.
Come Lodowick, and close vp my night-vaild eies
That neuer may agen behold the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: What meanes Mathias?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Hold me not Prince Otho.
I will reuenge my selfe vpon my selfe▪
For Parricide for damned parricide:
I haue kild my brother sleeping in the armes
Of the diuinest forme that e're held breath.
I haue kild loues Queene defac't with my foule hand,
The goodliest frame that euer nature built
And driuen the graces from the mansion
Wherein they haue continued from their birth;
She now being dead, shee'l dwell no more on earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What mooued you to it brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Iealous rage, suspition by Prince Otho,
That Lucibell had fled with a base Greeke,
Oh me accursed! I am borne to shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: But I am wretcheder, that from the lou
Deuoted to the house of Saxony,
Haue thus begot this monster cruelty:
I lay within an arbour, whence I saw
The princesse, and your selfe in this disguise
Departing secretly my vncles court:
I iudg'd you for a Greeke as you appear'd.
Told Prince Mathias of your secret flight;
And hee led on by fury followed you
Where thus deceased by night and your attire,
Hath rob'd your heart of life, his owne of ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Forgiue me brother, pardon fairest maide,
And ere the icy hand of ashie death
Fod your faire bodies in this sable vaile;
Discouer why you put on this disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: To scape the lustfull Duke of Prussia,
Who purpos'd this night to murder me,
And rauish her whom death hath made his pray
My Lucibell, whose lights are mask't with clouds
That neuer will be cleard.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: My vncle, fie, who buz'd into your head
This damned lie?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: it's no lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Noe lie: 'tis true, 'tis true,
The reuerent Hermet Rodorick told it vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: The Hermet is a villaine damn'd in hell
Before the worlds creation, if he sai't
My Princely vncle purpos'd such a thought.
Looke to the Princesse, ther's life in her:
Cheere vp your heart Prince Lodowicke, courage man.
Your being of comfort may recouer her,
While I bring forth the Hermet and disprooue
This false assertion: Rodorick is a slaue
A vile and irreligious hypocrite,
No Hermet, but a diuell if he dare
Affirme such falshood of Duke Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: Rodorick is not as you report him sir,
Nor did he erebelie Duke Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: No did? why then did you maliciously
Aduise Prince Lodowick and faire Lucibell
To flie the Prussian court this dismall night.

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: Who I? I spake not with them,

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.L: Yes ye did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Where was it that he spake with you? tell vs where?

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.L: At Dantzike in the Duke of Prussias court.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Who heard him besides you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: The Princesse Lucibell.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: As heauen shall helpe my fleeting soule, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: why speakes my dukedomes hope in hollow sounds?
Looke vp fayre child heer's Saxony and I
Thy father, Lucibella looke on me;
I am not angry that thou fled'st away
But come to grace thy nuptials; prithee speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Luci.
SP.L: Father I thanke you: Lodowick reach me thy hand
How cold thou art; death now assailes our hearts,
Hauing triumph't ouer the outward parts;
Farewell a while, we die but part, to meete
Where ioyes are certaine, pleasures endlesse, sweet.
Father, this latest boone of you I craue,
Let him, and me, lie in one bed, and graue.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Oh me! oh miserable wretched me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Houer a little longer blessed soule, glide not away too fast: mine now forsaks his earthly man∣sion and on hopes gilt wings will gladly mount with thine, where Angels sing celestiall ditties to the King of Kings. brother adew, your rashnesse I forgiue, pardon me father, pardon; Austria your daughter is become a bride for death: the dismall euen before her wedding day. Hermet God pardon thee: thy double tongue hath caus'd this errour: but in peace farewell. Hee that lifts vs to Heauen keepe thee from Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Oh strange coniecture! what should moue this Prince
To charge me with such horrid cruelty?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Ile tell thee hypocrite.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax
SP.L: Stay Mathias stay,
is thy vncle Rodorigo, and besides,
My hon or and Duke Austria's shall bee gag'd,
He neuer parted from our company in his owne hermitag
Since day declinde, and glimmering twilight vsher'd in the night.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Not from his hermitage?

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Noe not he.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: 'st possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: By Heauen he did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Then there is villany, practice, and villainy
Mathias hath bin wrong'd and drawne to kill
His naturall brother, with him to destroy
The rarest peece of natures workmanship,
No doubt by practize and base villany
The Hermet not at court? strange! wondrous!

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Oh for my fonne, and Austria's worthy childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Thou weep'st in scorne, and very teare of thine
Cours a smile: Saxony, I defie
All truce, all league of loue, guard thee prowd Duke;
Thy sonnes haue made me childlesse; Ile haue thee
Conort in death with my wrong'd girle and mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Helpe Prince Mathias: Hermet, oh the Heauens!
The Austrian Duke sinkes downe vpon the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Proud Iohn of Saxony: ha'st thou no wound?

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Not any Austria; neither toucht I thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Aust.
SP.L: Somebody toucht me home: vaine world farewell
Dying I fall on my dead Lucibell.

SP.SPEAKER: Saxo.
SP.L: Sir what are you that take on you to parte?
It's by your weapon that the Duke is falne.

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: If I thought so, i'de fall vpon the point,
But I am innocent of such an ill:
Kill my good kinsman, Duke of Austria;
Then were Prince Otho of Luningberg set downe
In sad dispaires blacke booke to raue and die;
But I am free from such imprety.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Are you Prince Otho of Luningberg?

SP.SPEAKER: Rodo.
SP.L: He is, and heire apparent to Duke Ferdinan

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: May be the Moone deceaues me, and my grief
As well in the distinguishing of sounds,
As sight: I haue heard of young Luningberg,
And seene him to at Hoffmans ouerthrow,
He lookt not like you, neither spake like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Father, 'tis he: Lorrique his man attends him,
That fellow which is all compos'd of mirth
Of mirth? of death: why should I thinke of mirth
After so foule a murder? come lend hands
To giue this Princely body funerall rites,
That I may sacrifice this hand and heart
For my peace-offerings on theyr sepulchers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Nay, boy, thou shall not leaue old Saxony
Childles for all this sorrow: Prince, and if Otho
Helpe in my son with noble Austria,
Lodowick shalbe my burden: brother yours
The louely but the lucklesse Lucibell.
So treade a heauy measure; now lets goe
To interre the dead, our hearts being dead with woe.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Ther's life in Lucibell, for I feele
A breath, more odoriferous then balme
Thirle through the corrall poras of her lipps,
Apparent signes of life, her puses beate;
Oh if I could but yet recouer her,
T'would satisfie the State of Austria,
That else would be disturb'd for want of heires
Heauen be propitious, guide my artlesse hand,
To preserue fainting life in this cleare forme.
Graunt this thou soule of all Diuinity,
And I will striue what euer mortall may
To serue thee on my knees both night and day.
Tarry Prince Otho and see theyr bodies balm'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: I pray you thinke me not in passion dull;
I must withdraw, and weepe, my heart is full.
Oh reuerent man, thou bearst the richest fruite;
That euer fell in the vnripired spring,
Goe lay her soft, she had ill fatero fall;
But rich or faire or strong, death swallowes all,
Hol! Lorrique, leaue our horse; draw neere.
Helpe me to sing a hymne vnto the fates
Compos'd of laughing interiections.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Why my good Lord? what accidents
Haue chanc't, that tickle so your spleene?

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Oh my deere selfe: thou trusty treasurer of my re∣uenge
Kneele downe, and at my bidding kisse the earth;
And on her cold eare whisper this strict charge:
That she prouide the best of her perfumes,
The fat of Lambs rap't from the bleating Ewes,
The sweetest smelling wood she can deuise;
For I must offer vp a sacrifice,
To blest occasion that hath seconded
With opportune meanes my desire of wreake▪

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Now I haue kis't the earth, let me pertake
In your great ioy, that seemes to exceed.
Are Lodowick, and the Princesse murder'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Tis done, goe, hie thee to Prince Ferdinand;
Tell him how misaduenture and mistrust
Hath kild Prince Lodowick and bright Lucibell:
By Prince Mathias hand: adde to that chaunce,
Another vnexpected accident:
Say that the Dukes of Austria and Saxony,
Being by the Hermet Rodorick intertain'd,
And hearing outcries in the dead of night,
Came and beheld the tragick spectacle,
Which sight did so inrage the Austrian Duke,
That he, assail'd the Saxon, but fell slaine,
On his daughter, now defloured by death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Is Austria then slaine by Saxony?

SP.SPEAKER: Hoff.
SP.L: Come, come, hee's dead, eyther by him or me,
Noe matter, hee's gone: ther's more to goe.
Runne with the newes; away.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Stilt, and a rabble of poore souldiers: old Stilt his father, with hi scarfe like a Captaine. A suruy march.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.L: Father, set you the army in qeraye, while I inuocate:
The Generall Foulkes: Fibs, forman, and
Friends all, Officers ail, helpe to marshall; Prince
Ierom my Lord shall remunerate that, is shall be
Full of thankesgiuing, while nature is able to
SP.P: Nourish, or sustayne; Father you haue order to stay the rest, be sententious, and full of circumstance I aduise you; and remember this, that more then mortality fights on our side; For we haue treason and iniquity to maintayne our quarrell.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Stilt.
SP.P: Hah! what say'st my sonne? treason and ini∣quity?

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Reason, and equity I meant Father; ther's little controuersity in the words: but like a Captaine couragi∣ous, I pray goe forward, remember the place you are, in noe more, but this; the dayes of old, no more, but that; and the glory Father; Knighthood at least, to the vtter defa∣cing of you and your posterity, Noe more but soe.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Stilt.
SP.P:
Well, goe thy waies: thou art able to put fire into a Flint stone; thou hast as rheumatique a tongue to
perswade as any is betweene Pole and Pomer; but thou art euen kitt after kind, I am thy father, and was infamous for my exprobations, to discourage a dissembly of tall souldiers afore thou wrt borne, and I haue made them stand to it tooth and nayle; how say you, most valiant and reprobate Country men: haue ye not heard I haue bin a stinger, a tickler, a wormer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fibs.
SP.P: Yet; noble, ancient Captaine Stilt, ye haue re∣mou'd mens hearts I haue heard that of my father (God rest his soule,) when yee were but one of the common all souldiers that seru'd old Sarloys in Norway.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Stilt.
SP.P: I then was, and Sarloys was; a gentleman wou'd not haue giuen his head for the washing; but hee is cut of, as all valiant caualeroes shall; and they be no more neg∣ligent of themselues; But to the purpose: wee are dissem∣bled together, and falne into batayle beray in the behalfe Prince Ierom a vertuous Prince, a wise Prince, and a most respectlesse Prince; my son Timothies master, and the vn∣lawfull heire of this land. Now sir the old Duke has put out a declamation, and saies our rising is noe other then a re∣surrection, for the Prince inspires not against his father; but the Duke inspires against his son, vsing him most natu∣rally, charitably, and abhominably, to put him from inter∣cession of the crowne; wherefore as yee bee true men, and obstinate subiects to the State vncouer your heads, and cast vp your caps and cry a Ierom, a Ierom,
Om, A Ierom, a Ierom, a Ierom.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P:
Most noble Countrymen I cannot but cond le in ioy, and smile in teares to see you assembled in my right, but this is the lamentation that I poore Prince must make, who for my fathers proclamation am like for to
loose my head; except you stand to mee, for they are com∣ming on with bowes, bills, and guns, against vs: but if you be valiant, and stand to me lustily, allth' earth 'shall roare but wee'l haue victory.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter with Drum, and Colours, Duke Ferdinand, Hoffman Lorrique, Captaiue to leade the drum the souldiers march and make a stand; All on Ieroms side cast vp their caps and cry a Ierom.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Vpon those traytors valiant gentlemen:
Let not that bea the multitude confront,
With garlicke-breath and their confused cries
The Maiesty of me their awfull Duke,
Strike their Typhoean body downe to fire
That dare 'gainst vs, their soueraigne conspire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: Come, come, you shall haue your hands full, and you
Come where we haue to doe, stand to it Stilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: stand to't? heer's the father and the son will stand, though all the rest flie away.

SP.SPEAKER: O Stilt.
SP.P: I warrant you Prince, when the battaile comes to ioyning, my son and I will bee inuisible, and they ouer∣come vs, ile giue you leaue to say I haue no pith in me; vp∣on vm true Prince vpon vm.

DIV2.STAGE: An Alarum: Hoffman kneeles betweene the Armies.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.L: I thought twou'd come to that;
I thought we shou'd bring
The false Prince on his knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: What meanes my Dukedomes hope to turne thus base? arise, and smite thy fos.

SP.SPEAKER: Srl.
SP.L: I see them not my most honor'd vncle; pittie I beseech
These silly people, that offend as babes,
Not vnderstanding, how they doe ffend:
And sffer me chiefe agent in this wrong,
To plead their pardons with a peacefull tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.L: We scorne pardons, Peace and pitty; Wee'l
haue a Prince of our owne chusing, Prince Ierom.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Stilt.
SP.P: I, I, Prince lorom or no body; be not obstacle old Duke, let not your owne flesh and blood bee inherited of your Dukedome, and a stranger displac'd in his retority: for and you doe, wee will take no comparison of you and your army, but fall vpon you like temperance and light∣ning.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Vpon your perill; gentlemen assayle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: If any bosome meete the brunt of war,
Mine shall be first oppos'd; these honest men
That rise in armes for my young Cozens right
Shall be Protected whil'st Prince Charles can stand.

SP.SPEAKER: ler.
SP.L: Why see now what a thing Maiesty is;
Stilt and the rest of my good people; my couzen)
Charles looking but in the face of our excellence
Cannot choose but take our parte.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.L: Nay but trust him not my Lord; take heed of him,
Aware your enemies at any hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Why should you make this intercession
For these base abiects, whose presumptuous hearts
Haue drawne their rebell bodies 'gainst their head:
Intreat not for them, they are all but dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Forbeare a little worthy Countrymen.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Nay we deny that, weare none of your Countrymen; you are an arant arrant Alien.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Stilt.
SP.P: True son uncere peregrination, and one that was not borne within our Dukes damnation, and therefore not to be remitted to any vpstantiall degree of office amongst vs: that's the fine, that's the confusion of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.P: But heare mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: I, I▪ pray heare him; nay I charge you all vpon paine of death that you heare my cozen.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: he Well wee will are him: come on, speake, what wlil yee say?

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: O I beseech you saue your liues and goods,
For the Dukes squadrons arm'd with wrath and death,
Watch but the signall when to ceaze on you,
That can noe more with stand their approoued strengthes
Then sparrowes can contend with towring hawks:
Or 'gainst the Eagles ayer:
This act of yours by gathering to a head,
Is treason capitall, and without grace
Your liues are forfeit to extreamest law.

SP.SPEAKER: O Stilt.
SP.L: Mas he saies true son; but what's the remedy?

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: None at all father, now wee are in, wee must goe through stitch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Yes, there is remedy: cast your weapons downe,
And arme your selues with mercy of your Prince
Who like a gracious shepheard ready stands
To take his lost sheepe home in gentle hands.
As for your Prince, I will for him intreat
That he may be restor'd againe in loue,
And vnto offices of dignity, as eyther Taster,
Sewer, Cupbearer, the place himselfe thinkes
Fittest for his state, and for my part when
That vnhappy time of Princely Ferdinands
Sad death shall, come:—
Which moment:—
But should I as I say behold that houre,
Although I am elected for your Prince,
Yet would I not remooue this gentleman,
Bat rather serue him as his councellor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Giue me your hand of that Cozen; well sayd, now get a pardon for mee, and my merry men all; and then let me be my fathers Taster, being the office belonging to his eldest sonne; I Being the same, and then you shall see mee behaue my selfe, not as a rebell, or reprobate, but as a most reasonable Prince, and sufficient subiect.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P:
Well since my Lord ha's sayd the word, bring that of spake he to passe and ye shall haue my word too, and old Stilt my fathers, being a man of good reproch I tell you,
and condemnation in his country.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Stilt.
SP.P: I that I am my Lord, I haue liu'd in name and shame hese threescore, and seuen winters, all my neighbours can are me testament, and accord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Well, rest yee quiet; Soueraigne on my knees
I beg your Highnes graunt to there request:
Suppose them silly, simple, and your owne;
To shed their blood were iust, yet rigorous,
The praise of Kings is to prooue gracious.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: True soule of honor, substance of my selfe,
Thy merit wins thee mercy, goe in peace,
Lay by your vniust armes, liue by your sweate,
And in content the bread of quiet eate.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.L: Godsaue Duke Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: Pray Father, forgiue me, and my man,
And my mans father by our single selues;
For we haue bin the capitall offendors.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Stilt
SP.L: I truely my Lord, we rais'd the resurrection,

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: I pardon all; giue thee my Tasters place:
Honor this Prince that hath thus won you grace.

SP.SPEAKER: O. S.
SP.L: Y-S. God saue Duke Ferdinand, and Prince Otho.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: I and me too.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Stilt.
SP.P: And Prince Ierom too; well son, ile leaue thee a Courtier still, and get mee home to my owne desolation, where ile labour to compell away excessity: and so fareyee well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: This busines ouer: worthy nephew Charles,
Let vs goe visi the sad Saxon Duke,
The mourning Hermet,
That through affection wrought his brothers fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Ile wait your Highnes to that house of woe,
Where sad mischance sits in a purple chayre,
And vnderncath her beetle cloudy browes
smiles at vnlockt for mischsefes; oh there
Doth griefe vnpainted, in true shape appeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Shrill trumpets sound a flourish
For the cryes of war are drownd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier,
SP.L: Nay but cozen cozen, i'st not necessary I wait
Vpon myne owne father? and stilt vpon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: It's most expedient, be obsequious.
Noe doubt his xcellence will le that well.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lorrique like a French Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Dieu vou guard Mounsieur.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Welcome my friend, ha'st any suit to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Away Mounsieur, if you be the grand Princ
Legitimate of Prussia, I haue for tendre
To your Excellence de service of one poore
Gentle home of Champaigne.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: I am not he you looke for gentlemen,
My cozen is the true and lawfull Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: I sir I am the legitimate, and am able to entertayne
A gentleman though I say't and he be of any quality,

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl,
SP.L: Lorrique, now or neuer play thy part:
This Act is euen our Tragedies best hart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Let me alone for plots, and villany,
Onely commend me to this foole the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: I tell thee, I am the Prince, my cozen knowes it,
That's my cozen, this is stilt my man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: A vostree seruice Mounsieur most Genereux.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Noe doubt he is some cunning gentleman
Your Grace may doe a deede befitting you
To entertaine this stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: It shall bedone cozen; ile talke with him a little
And follow you, goe commend me to my father
SP.P: Tell him I am comming, and Stilt, and this stranger, bee mindfull cozen, as you will answere to my Princely in∣diguation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Well sir, I will be carefull, neuer doubt;
Now scarlet Mistris from thicke sable clouds
Thrust forth thy blood-staind hands, applaud my plot,
That giddy wonderers may amazed stand
While death smytes downe suspectles Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Sweet Prince I scarce vnderstand this fellow well, but I like his conceit in not trusting Prince otho; you must giue him the remooue that's flat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I be, gar, hee be chose agen you, hee giue you good worde so be dat, but he will haue one fisgig or dia by gar for company on in principality be no possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Well, I apprehend thee, I haue a certaine Princely feeling in my selfe that he loues me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Hold yee there my Lord, I am but a poore fellow and haue but a simple liuing left me; yet my brother were he a very naturall brother of mine owne, should hee be dopted, I would dopt him, and herrite him, i'le fit him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: I but how Stilt, but how?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: By gar my Lord, I will tell you fine knacks, for make him kicke vp his heeles, and cry wee, or be gar I be hange, and so shall I be to, and for de grand loue I beare you, for de Lady Issabella's sake your most tres-excellent Lady moder,

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Didst, thou know her French doctor? didst thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Silt.
SP.P: I as beggars doe the Ladies that are their Almesgi∣giuers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: By gar you lye, like Iacknape, I loue de Lady.
With a boone coeur, and for her sake here take dissame, and dis same, put dis in de cup, where de competitor Prince otho shall drinke; by gar it will poyson him brauely.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: That were excellent my Lord, and it could be done, and noe body know on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: I, but he alwaies drinkes in my Fathers cup.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I so let be, let de Duke drinke a de same.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: What poyson my father? noe, I like not that so well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: You shall drinke too, and I too and when wee bee sicke, as we shall baue as shall haue a petit rumble in de belly; dan take a dis same, and giue your sadra dis: but your cozin none of it, and bygar noe body shall be dead, and kicka, and cry oh, but Otho.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: That's excellent, master;

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: This is the poyson then, and this is the medicine?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I dat be true.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Well Phisitian, attend in my chamber heere, till Stilt and I returne; and if I pepper him not, say I am not wor∣thy to be cald a Duke, but a drawlatch.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Farewellawe, and iebbit a vow; and wee speede by thy practice wee'l crush a cup of thine owne country wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: Goe speede to spoyle your selues.
Doctor lie there, Lorrique, like thy selfe appeare
So now ile post vuto the Hermitage, and smile
While silly fooles act treason act through my guile.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus quartus.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Ferdinand and Sarlois, open a curtaine: Kneele Saxony, the Hermet and Mathias: tapers burning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: See Princely vncle blacke dormitory,
Where Austria and Prince Lodowick are layd
On the cold bed of earth, where they must sleepe
Till earth and ayre, and sea consume by fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Their rest be peace, their rising glorious;
Sad mourners, giue your partners leaue to kneele,
And make their offertorie on this tombe,
That does containe the honourablest earth
That euer went vpright in Germany,

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Welcome Duke Ferdinand, come, come, keele, kneele▪
Thus should each friend anothers sorrow feele.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Is Lucibella in this monument?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.L: Noe, shee's recouer'd from deaths violence;
But through her woundes and griefe distract of sence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Heauen helpe her, here she comes;

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Kneele still, I pay.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh mee accurst I why liue I this blacke day▪

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: Oh a sword, I pray you kill me not,
For I am going to the riuers side.
To fetch white lillies, and bew daffadils
To sticke in Lodowicks bosome, where it bled,
And in mine owne; my true loue is not dead,
Noe y'are deceiud in him, my father is:
Reason he should, he made me run away▪
And Lodowick too, and you Mathias too;
Alacke for woe, yet what a the remedy?
We must run all awaye: yet all must dye.
'Tis soe, I wrought it in a sampler,
'Twas heart in hand, and true loues knots and words,
All true stitch by my troth: the posie thus:
No flight deare loue but death, shall seuer vs;
Nor that did not neyther; he lies here does he not?

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Yes louely madam, pray be patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: Iso I am, but pray tell me true,
Could you be patient, or you, or you, or you,
To loose a father and a husband too:
Yee could, I cannot; open, doore here hoe!
Tell Lodowick, Lucibell would speake with him;
I haue newes from heauen for him, he must not dy,
I haue rob'd Prometheus of his moouing fire:
Open the dore, I must come in, and will,
Ile beate my selfe to ayre, but Ile come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Alas her tender hands smiting the ston
Beweepe their mistris rage in teares of blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Faire Lady be of comfort, t'is in vaine
To inuocate the dead to life againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: I gentle Daughter be content, I pray▪
Their fate is come, and ours is not, far off.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Here is a hand ouer my fate hath power▪
And I now sinke vnder the stroke of death,
But that a purer spirit fils my brest
And guides me from the footsteps of dispaire,

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: A heauenly motion full of charity,
Your selfe to kill you selfe were such a sinne
As most diuines hold deadly.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: I but a knaue may kill one by a tricke,
Or lay a plot, or soe, or cog, or prate,
Make strife, make a mans father hang him,
Or his brother, how thinke you goodly Prince,
God giue you ioy of your adoption;
May nor trickes be vsd?

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Alas poore Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: I thats true, I am poore, and yet haue things,
And gold ring, and amidst the leaues greenea
Lord how dee, well I thanke god, why thats well,
And you my Lord, and you too; neuer a one weepe,
Must I shed all the teares? well he is gone,
And he dwells here ye sayd, ho i'le dwell with him,
Death, dastard, Diuell, robber of my life
Thou base adulterer, that partst man and wife
Come I defie thy darts.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: O sweet for beare.
For pitties sake a while her rage restraine
Last she doe violence vpon herselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: O neuer feare me, there is somewhat cri
Within menoe: tels me there's knaues abroad
Bids mee be quiet, lay me downe and sleepe
Good night good gentlefolkes, brother your hand,
And yours good father, you are my father now,
Doe but stand here, l'fe sun a little course
At base, or barley-breake, or some such toye,
To catch the fellow, and come backe againe,
Nay looke thee now, let goe, or by my troth
Ile tell my Lodowick how yee vse his loue:
Soe now god-buye, now god-night indeede:
Lie further Lodowick▪ take not all the roome,
Be not a churle, thy Lucibell doth come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Follow her brother, follow son Mathies,
Be carefull guardians of the troubled mayd;
While I conerre with Princely Ferdinand
About an embassie to Aüstria,
With true reports of there disasterous haps.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Well, I will be her guardian and her guide,
By me her sences haue bin weakned,
But i'le contend with charitable paine,
To serue her, till they be restord againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: A vertuous, noble resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Worthy Prince Rodorigo, when tempestuous woe
Abates her violent storme, I shall haue time
To chide you for vnkindenes, that haue liu'd
In solitary life with vs so long.
Beleue me Saxon Prince you did vs wrong:

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Would I might neuer liue in noe worse state;
For contemplation is the path to heauen.
My new conversing in the world is prou'd
Lucklesse and full of sorrow; fare-ye-well
My heauens, alone, all company seemes hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: My nephew call for winemy soule is dry
I am sad at sight of soe much misery.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter I erom and Stilt, with cup, towell, and wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Is the Dukes taster there?

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: I am at hand with my office.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Fill for the Duke good cozen, tast it first.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: I haue no minde to it Stilt, for all my antidote.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.L: I warrant you Master let Prince Otho drinke next,

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: Heere cozen, will you begin to my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: I thanke you kindly, i'le not be so bold,
It is your office; fill vnto my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Well god be with it, it's gon downe, and now ile send the medicine after; Father pray drinke to my cozen for hee is soe mannerly that hee'l not drinke before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Pray yee doe my Lord, for Prince Otho is best wor∣thy of all this company to drinke of that cup, which and he doe, I hope he shall nere drinke more.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer,
SP.P: Good for tune after all this sorrow Saxony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.P: O worthy Ferdinand, fortune and I are parted, she has playd the minion with mee, turn'd all her fauours in to frownes, and in scorne rob'd mee of all my hopes, and in one houre o're turnd mee from the top of her proud wheele.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Build not on fortune, shee's a sickle dame
And those that trust vnto her spheare are fooles.
Fill for his Excellence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Here cozen for your Excellence, pray drinke you to the Duke of Saxony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Not I kind cozen, I list not to drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Gods Lady, I thinke Stilt, wee are all vndone, for I feele a iumbling worse and worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: O giue the Duke some of the medicine

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: What medicine talk'st thou of? what ayles my son?

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: O lord, father, and yee meane to be a liues man take some of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Why? this is deadly poyson vnprepar'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: True, but it was prepar'd for you and mee by an ex∣cellent fellow, a french Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: I, he is one that had great cqre of you.

SP.SPEAKER: For,
SP.L: Villaine what was he? drinke not Saxony
I doubt I am by treason poyson'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.P: Heauen keepe that fortune from my dread Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ler.
SP.L: Treason ye Princes, treason to the liues
Of Ferdinand the Dke of Prussia
My Princely master! Otho of Luningberg

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.P: Who should intend vs treason?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: This fond Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Neuer to you Father, but to my cozen Charles▪ indeede I meant to poyson him, but I haue pepperd my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.P: I neuer gaue thee cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: That's nothing to the purpose, but my Lord tooke occasion by the councell of a French Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.P: Physitians for the Duke, y vncie faints.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Surgeons for the Prince, my master falls.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Call no Phisitians, for I feel't too late,
The subtill poyson mingled with my blood
'Nums all the passages, and nimble death
Fleetes on his prple currents to my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: Father, I am dying too, oh now I departe,
Be good to Stilt my man, he was accessary
to all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Stils.
SP.P: I truely: was I sir therefore I hope you'le be good to me, I helpt to mingle the poyson as the French Doctor, and my master charged me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: What's that French Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.P: What's become of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Wee left him in the court in my masters cham∣ber.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.L: I sir woe worth him, farewell Stilt, farewell fathers
I aske you pardon with repentant eyes;
Fall stars, O Stilt, for thus thy master dyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Take hence that maytor for the foole his man.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: I pray prouide for me sit;

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Let him be tortur'd, then vpon a wheele
broke like a traytor and a murderer.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt,
SP.P: O lord sir. I meant you noe hurt, but to Prince Charles

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.P: Away, distur be vs not with idle talke.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Prouide quoth a and you call this prouiding, pray let mee, prouide for my selfe, alas my poore father, hee'le creepe vppon crutches into his graue when, he heares his proper'st Stilt is cut off by the stumpes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Hence with that fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Stilt.
SP.P: Pray, not soe hasty, you would scarce bee soe forward, and you were going as I am, to the gal∣lowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: How cheares my royall vncle

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Likea ship that hauing long contended with
The waues, is at last with one proud billow
Smit into the ruthlesse swallow of the sea.
For thee alas I perceiue this plot was lay de;
But heauen had greater mercy-on hy youth,
And one my people, that shall finde true rest
Being with a Prince so wise and vertuous blest.
Farewell most noble Iohn of Saxony,
Beare thy vnmatched griefe with a minde bent
Against the force of all temptations;
By my example Princely brother, see,
How vaine our liues and all our glories bee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: God for thy mercy! treason vpon treason,
How now yong Otho what art thou poyson'd too?

SP.SPEAKER: Sarl.
SP.L: Would God I were, but my sad starrs reserue
This simple building for extreamer ruine:
Oh that French doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.L: I that worst of hell.
Noe torment shall content vs in his death.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax.
SP.L: Nay soft and faire, let him be taken first;
How now sad brother, are you come to see
This Tragicke end of worthy Ferdinand?

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: I heard of it too soone, and come too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Sax
SP.L: Well brother leaue the Duke, and waite on mee▪
Mathias, and the heartgreiu'd Lucibell
Shall goe with vs to Wittenberg, and shun
That fatall land fild with destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
